bestBHT.bht: Everyone who calls upon the name of the Lord, specifically Jesus Christ, will be saved. This declaration by the Apostle Paul is a strong proof of Christ's divinity, as he unequivocally applies the name and attributes of Jehovah to Him. The inclusionary term everyone whosoever emphasizes the universality of this promise, making no distinctions. Peter's reference to this confirms its relevance to Christ. Calling upon the Lord involves acknowledging His sovereignty and making a loyal surrender, resulting in an inseparable connection between this calling and eternal salvation.

Henry Alford: Scripture proof of this assertion: every one whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.

There is hardly a stronger proof, or one more irrefragable by those who deny the Godhead of our Blessed Lord, of the unhesitating application to Him by the Apostle of the name and attributes of Jehovah.
(Jehovah,—but used here of Christ beyond a doubt, as the next verse shews.)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Everyone whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
Quoted also by Peter, in his great Pentecostal sermon, with evident application to Christ.
Albert Barnes: To call on the name of the Lord is the same as to call on the Lord himself.
To call upon him is to acknowledge him as our Sovereign, our Father, and our Friend; and it is right that we render him our homage.
He will cast none away who come in this manner. The invitation and the assurance extend to all nations and to people of all times.
Philip Schaff: The prophecy refers to ‘Jehovah,’ but in His final revelation of Himself, if Christ is meant in Romans 10:12, then this prophecy is applied 'justly to Christ, who has appeared in the name of God, and continually rules as His Representative and Revealer, and Mediator, whose name was now the very specific object of the Christian calling on the Lord.'

When...this author speaks of this 'calling' as not being 'the worshipping absolutely,' but rather 'worship according to that relativity in the consciousness of the worshipper, which is conditioned by the relation of Christ to the Father,' he is unsupported by the records of Christian experience.

The heart of the believer, calling upon Jesus as Lord, makes a loyal surrender to Him, and in its joyous devotion to the Master, is not apt to make this distinction between absolute and relative worship, a distinction which is not in accordance with Biblical monotheism, and is verbal rather than real.
John Gill: all that call upon the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, will find him rich and plenteous in mercy, and ready to dispense his grace and salvation to them
be they who they will, whether Jews or Gentiles; not with a temporal salvation only, but with a spiritual and eternal one
between which call and eternal glory, there is a certain and inseparable connection

bhtAttempts.bht: Scripture unequivocally states that anyone who calls upon the name of the Lord, specifically Jesus Christ, will be saved. This declaration serves as a powerful testament to Christ's divinity, as the Apostle boldly attributes to Him the name and attributes of Jehovah. The phrase everyone whosoever emphasizes the inclusiveness of this promise, leaving no room for exclusion or discrimination. Furthermore, Peter corroborates this truth by referencing the same passage in his Pentecostal sermon, underscoring its application to Christ. To call upon the Lord is to acknowledge His sovereignty, fatherhood, and friendship, while also making a surrender and devotion to Him. This invitation and assurance extend to all nations and people of all times, providing a certain and inseparable connection between this calling and eternal salvation.
